text: Bottle. Golden body with a large, frothy, white head. Aroma of toasted grain, floral hops, musty basement, apricot. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. A straightforward tripel and thats good. It has none of the overwhelming clove spice, banana and annoying sweetness of many American tripels. Plenty of depth and Belgian character. Taste of honey, light lemon, floral hops, light mustiness. Delicious.

I drink this beer with a lasagna and spicy food, not sure that I would pair it with spicy food thanks bye

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle. Clear, deep orangey, copper-ish golden colour with average to huge, thick, fluffy, fairly lasting and lacing, off-white head. Fruity hoppy and sweet-ish malty aroma, notes of apricot. Taste is moderately sweet malty with minimally sugary, bready and biscuity touch, hints of honey, fruity, yeasty notes of apricot find further fruity hop support. New World hop addendum accounts for facility and drinkability due to an avoidance of tackiness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle. Clear, deep orangey, copper-ish golden colour with average to huge, thick, fluffy, fairly lasting and lacing, off-white head. Fruity hoppy and sweet-ish malty aroma, notes of apricot. Taste is moderately sweet malty with minimally sugary, bready and biscuity touch, hints of honey, fruity, yeasty notes of apricot find further fruity hop support. New World hop addendum accounts for facility and drinkability due to an avoidance of tackiness.

DATE: May 7, 2017.... OCCASION: Game night is over, but Game of Thrones-themed beer never fails to deliver... GLASSWARE: Duvel tulip snifter.... pours a medium amber body that floats some serious driftwood as sediment... the head is white as the North, just as resilient and foamy with appropriate lacing.... a swirling centrifuge twists violently in its midst... lacing is appreciable and organized... first aroma kicks of banana, bubblegum. candied apple, honey, and toasted oats--quite a nostril full... the impact of its sip is full on at the teeth, with an awakening of the throat as well... medium-bodied, but no fooling its 9% ABV--and no apologies, considering its namesake... the wheat is detectable, making for a deliciously soft balance between the oats and hops (which suggest Saaz or Tettnanger) that evokes a breezy, flowery setting--perfect for a spring night such as this... goodness, there is something strange at work in this one, like Arya Starks time in the House of White and Black.... should this be celebrated as a tremendous one-off with distinctive character, or written off as simply another fine Ommegang Belgian that will sneak up and hammer my consciousness once I finish it? God bless Ommegang for their tireless work to bring savory Belgian fare with subtle variations that make each release a celebration in its own right.... short lived but highly recommended....

Bottle purchased at Gezelig. Mildly yeasty and wheaty aroma, pours opaque amber with some sediment remaining. Retains head fairly well and is on the more carbonated end which makes it more refreshing. Taste is Apricot and honey, slightly floral and yeasty and boozy woody finish. This is a fairly classic Belgian tripel, I was mainly forced to buy it by the SO because of the Game of Thrones reference - though I cant say I regret trying it.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2017 Beautiful hazy apricot - cider pour, medium white head. Wonderful sweet aroma with lots of bananas, cloves, apricots, spices, and caramel. Taste follows, rich, sweet and fruity.

750ml bottle from beergium.com Kotkankadun tasting.


Golden colour with a white head. Spices, fruits, mild yeast, refreshing!

Bottle. Light hazy golden with a large off white head with good retention, lace and regeneration. Floral nose with some citrus and minerals also. The flavour follows with honey, flowers, minerals, light golden bread. Full body, soft mouthfeel with mild sweetness and bitterness. Warming alcohol. Long finish.

Thin off white head of fine bubbles. Low carbonation for a Belgian. Sweet malty a bunch of earthy overtones. Light fruit, dried grains, spices and straw. Color is a murky golden brown. Plenty of carbonation life in the mouth. Bubbles explode with the sip. More earthy malts, straw, herbal hops, dried flowers and tangerine. Moderate alcohol presence. Dry palate with some lingering spices. A pretty good Belgian which is expected from Ommegang.

Poured from 750ml bottle. 

About a centimeter of clear golden liquid below a huge off-white head that left only fair lacing. 

Aroma of citrus, yeast, tropical fruit, banana, cloves and caramel. 

Taste of tropical fruit, yeast, citrus, cloves, honey and banana. 

Medium body and medium/high carbonation with a nice mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
All the aroma, head and yeast that this style dictates. On closeout for $20/case with 2018 best buy. I cant figure---but will stock up!!!

1/2/17. Bottle. Golden pour with a nice off-white head. Nice aroma, hints of Belgian yeast meld with pale malts, sweetness, candi sugars, a floral touch, and a whiff of honey. Good flavor as well, lovely sweetness without being unbalanced, hints of sugar, honey, floral aspects, tangerine, and pale malts. Tasty!

750ml corked bottle. Pils malt aroma with notes of wheat malt, candi sugar, Belgian yeast and a little bit of honey. Pours dark golden colored with one finger of off white head that has excellent retention and good lacing. Starts with pils and wheat malt flavors with sweet candi sugar notes. Finishes smooth and dry with a bit of honey sweetness and spicy Belgian yeast. Very nice tripel.

My 5,000 rating!! The appearance is a huge frothy off-white head that is fully lasting, transparent golden body, fast rising, carbonation observed, and a fair amount of lacing. The aroma presents citrus hops, tropical fruit, banana, yeast, grainy, peppery, floral, spicy, honey, clove, sweetness, and caramel malt. The flavor presents citrus hops, light bitterness, tropical fruit, yeast, grainy, clove, banana, light pepper, spicy, light honey, caramel malt, and a semi-dry finish. This beers mouthfeel is lively carbonation and semi-warming. This beer is light-medium bodied. This is a great selection for my 5,000th rating! It is a very tasty sipping beer and a beer that is one of my favorite beer styles. The various flavors combined very well which makes this a very enjoyable beer to drink and rate. It is worth trying and a beer that I would definitely drink again and again and again!! Cheers!!

Appearance is a dark golden color with a white head and excellent lacing. The aroma contains some citrus, honey, candi sugars, and spices. The flavor is a bit on the sweet side with some honey, butterscotch, and citrus. Some mild herbal notes are also present. The mouthfeel is also a bit sweet but somewhat dry at the end. Overall a nice tripel.

750 ml caged and corked bottle. Pours a deep honey gold color. Medium sized creamy white head disappates quickly. Nose is sweet malt with notes of honey and yeast. Semi sweet grainy malt flavor has a touch of candi sugar and booze. Lovely subtle carbonation. Dry, warming alcohol finish. Very true to the style.

Love the larger corked bottle that starts this experience off with a great "pop." Game Of Thrones Valar Dohaeris is a solid tripel with a nice Belgian aroma of spice, fruit, grain, toffee, yeast and malt. It pours a bubbly white-golden color that turns hazy-clear gold with a tall, white, healthy head leaving thick tufts of lace. Has the distinct Belgian malty flavor, balanced with hop notes, fruit and a light toffee-chocolate taste thats not too dry with a hoppy finish. This is a full bodied, nicely balanced Belgian Tripel.
Clove and flowers like the garlic lost in your flower pot. Hazy orange pour with good head and lacing. Light sweet finish. Hint of citrus. Good balance, pretty well put together. Bottle.
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty peppery aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty weak hoppy finish.
Bottle. Pours a hazed golden color with an average white head. Aroma of yeast, banana, honey and pepper. Flavor of honey, yeast, banana, candi sugar, citrus and had a subtle peppery spice.

Beautiful hazy orange hued pour into St. Feuillien snifter. Aromas of dried fruits, apricot and a hint sweet pineapple. Very juicy and sweet initially. More estery fruits, a bit of honey and vanilla. Finishes with a spicy and slightly dry that rounds out the palate well.

Pours a nice hazy golden. Nose is banana, Belgian yeast, stone fruit. Taste is dominated by peach, apple juice, candi sugar--too sweet for me at first. Better as it warmed up, with some clove, coriander(?) and dry grassy yeast notes cutting the sweetness on the finish. Lots of esters and some booziness. Nice mouth feel with fine carbonation. Very good, but slightly disappointing for Ommegang.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Peachy and light spicy yeast, some clove, mild sweetness, and a peachy fruity finish. Pretty good.
Wow, very tasty tripel. Taste was nicely balanced honey, fruity Belgian yeast, candi sugar, spice, bubblegum. Bubbly. Good stuff

Torpedo bottle. Pours a light copper color, very generous head. Aroma is honey, some Belgium sugar candy, grains, spice clove. Taste is medium light sweetness.. Honey and Belgium yeast and Belgium sugars in taste. Average carbonation. Some warming alcohol. Its pretty good.
Im not a huge fan of tripels, let alone American made attempts, but this one was firing on all cylinders. Aroma was nice. Belgian yeast, honey and assorted light fruit. Pour was a noce
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A lightly hazed golden blonde ale with a thin white head. In aroma sweet fruity malt with light coriander, curacao, light plums. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with candy sugar, alcohol warmth, curacao, coriander, light perfumy notes, pleasant. On tap at Maggies on the River.

Big bottle with commonmac . Hazy gold, maybe some sediment. Medium white head that clings. Smells of sweet yeast, nice aroma. Spice is prevalent, especially clove. Fuzzy yeast, light grain, banana. Spicy, fruity burn. Finish is a tiny bit metallic, overall it could have ended better . More sediment and funkier as you work down the bottle and I liked it even more. Excellent showing. Definitely serve me up another.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2017 Large bottle acquired as a Christmas gift from blonderedhead. Consumed during college football championship in a Belgian snifter glass with commonshawn. Quarter finger off white head. Yeast and spices on the nose with some banana. Cloudy golden orange color. Taste begins with a sweet, nearly bubblegum quality. Tropical fruit and a spiciness one would expect from a tripel. More sweetness as the sip progresses. The mouthfeel is drier than I anticipated. Gains a little funk on the second glass. Very enjoyable. Ommegang does this style well and succeeds again here. Im ready to serve myself another one.
Hazy orangeish color with a medium head. Yeasty, spiced aroma. Light biscuit. Dry, dusty wheat and honey flavor. Bready. Some light graininess. Full bodied.

750ml bottle into a snifter. Pours orange/golden with a big fluffy head. Yeast floaties. Smells sweet and doughy. Belgian yeast, banana & bubble gum. Taste is Belgian yeast, banana, clove, honey. Pleasant carbonation. A good complex triple. Yum

Bottle. Pours out a decent golden color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is of lots of sweet fruity yeast, dough, some banana, clove, light floral bitterness. Taste is solid, spot on for the style, sweet fruity yeast, grain, clove banana, dough and some mild bitterness on the end. Sweet dinner rolls.
Pours a copper color with a small head and lacing. tastes of yeast and dried fruits with no sugars. Has a dry mouthfeel and finish. Not my favorite tripel.

Bottle (750 ml). Pours orange-light copper color with off-white head and lacing. Nose of dried apricots and some yeastiness. Apricot is prevalent with orange notes. Effervescent mouthfeel. Dry finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Solid amber color, poured with a nice white head; both aroma and taste of moderate spices and sweetness. I have not had this style before and really enjoyed it. Definitely would try again.

750 mL bottle. Pours a cloudy copper color with a quick white head that settles but lingers. Aroma is of yeast, spice and a little sweet. Medium body, flavor is sweet with a little spiciness and yeast to it. Finish is just a touch dry. Excellent!
malty with very faint clove/banana aromas. golden and clear with huge foamy head that will not subside. taste is balanced, hints of citrus, banana, clove. finishes smooth and clean.
Pours a clear yellow-gold. A strong citrus and yeast aroma. A sweet citrus taste with pine, spices, wheat and yeast. A dry yeast and citrus aftertaste.

Bottle; pours cloudy amber with a white head; aroma of spice, yeast, fruits, and bit of sugar; taste is sweet with sugar, fruits, and caramel with some faint floral notes; finish is dry with some spices; pretty good

750 ml. Lightly foggy golden-orange body with a big foam that settles to a film fairly quickly. Aroma of earthy honey, toasted grain and a touch of zesty citrus. Flavors of honey with the beeswax, orange zest, evergreen resin and touches of wheat and bubblegum. Medium body is well to the dry side and has explosive, annoying carbonation.
Slightly hazy deep golden. Thick white foamy head with minimal dissapation. Banana, bubble gum, leather. Balanced with malty sweetness up front and a dry peppery finish.
Deep golden color.Huge , white head. Floral aroma with notes of banana , spices and bubble gum.Candy sugar , yeast , spices in dry taste. Another good beer from Ommegang.

750 mL bottle from Whole Foods Milwaukee 11/24/16. Hazy orange, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of doughy malt, pepper, marzipan, apricot, floral and herbal notes. The taste is bready malt, pepper, vinous notes, apricot, herbal notes. Medium bodied, lingering spice.
Bottle. Deep golden with big head. Slightly overcarbonated perhaps. Nice Tripel with bubblegum and banana. A bit on the dry side for the style. Slight booze. Very good.

bottle @ Chief Market / Lima OH --- Aroma of malt, grain, and honey. Cloudy, dirty dark amber color, beige head that quickly sinks to a cover, bands of lace. Taste is solid malt with honey, strong carbonation that becomes a little peppery on the tongue, then more malt, followed by light bittering that grows in a long finish. Big bodied, some alcohol, but solid, and for sure in the Belgian tradition. Another solid offering from Ommegang.

750 cc from Craft and from variety pack at Whole Foods PM. Hazy straw pour with off-white head. Nose is hopcitrus, yeasty funk, white pepper. Complex flavor, with notes of hops, citrus, yeast, funk, florals, and spice. Perhaps the best beer from Ommegang Ive had all year.
On tap at P&P Charleston. Slightly hazy golden with small white head. Aroma is light citrus, medium body, lower carbonation, and a little lacing. Taste is citrus and a little booze.

Floral and earthy notes play with sweetness in the aroma. It pours a clear golden with a giant white head, and visible carbonation. Theres a hint of honey in the beginning of the flavor, which fades to floral notes and a dry finish. The alcohol is very well hidden, and the carbonation is spot on. This is a great Tripel, and one that Im glad I picked up.
Aroma is Belgian yeast, spices and light lemon/fruit. The flavor is bananas, lemon, malts, fruit and a mix of tart and mild/medium sweetness in the finish.

750 ml bottle. Some clarity in a golden Amber liquid, thin lasting head. Aroma of spicy yeast, banana, citrus, and honey. 
Taste is sweet, mild alcohol, with fruity hops, black pepper. Some spicy finish with mild alcohol. Pretty well made.

Golden orange in color... Aroma of Belgian Candi sugar, honey, citrus... Flavor is crisp and fruity, red apples, Candi sugar, citrus, honey, light dry and yeasty finish... Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Birthday bomber #2. Nose is typical tripel with slight champagne notes. Definite candi sugars in this with the slight white pepper finish. Warming. Slight aggressive finish which might mellow out by aging this.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream head. Yeast and light spice aroma with fruity esters and light caramel. Caramel and light banana flavor with light yeast and light chocolate. Medium bodied. Caramel and light banana lingers with cake.

This is a good, bready, spicy beer. If youre familiar with Ommegangs other Game of Thrones offerings, I think Seven Kingdoms (blonde ale) comes closest. After the initial spice, the beer kind of disappears in terms of memorable flavor, but its a good beer overall. Just not as great as youd expect from a brewery famous for their Belgian products.
A nice spicy Belgium style. Has a nice malt base with strong spices, coriander, pepper.

750 ml bottle. Pours deep golden with tall, long-lasting, foamy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is peppery hops, pale malt, spices and ripe fruit. Body is medium and crisp. Citrusy hops, alcohol, Belgian yeast, candy sugar, bready malt and ripe fruit fill the mouth. Finish is long and dry. Wonderful brew.
Hazy yellow with an inch of white head. Aroma is light white grape. Taste is sort of the same, and drying, with relatively higjh bitterness into the finish. $8/750

Pours deep hazy gold into a tulip. Bright white head with excellent retention recedes leaving gloppy lacing. Sweet banana and yeast aromas. Sharp with summer fruit, honey and yeast upfront turning dry in the warming candi and bitter earth finish.
Bottle. A golden yellow color with a lush white head. A delightful tripel with a spicy flavor and aroma with a touch of sweetness. It holds up very well throughout.

From a big bottle into a tulip glass. Pours gold with head and lace. Aroma of amber malts, candy sugar, light haym scones. Significant carbonation and medium mouthfeel. Flavors of grains, amber malt, light candy sugar, citrus zest, Belgian yeast esters. Overall rich, complex, flavorful and tasty.
Medium gold pour, finger + of white head. Nose is honey, citrus, and honeydew melon. Finish is warm, bittersweet, and a little rummy.
Hazy golden color, moderate head, good lace/retention. Aroma is pepper, sugar, pale malt, lighter fruit. Medium bodied, fairly dry, fruity, one of the best Tripels Ive had in a long time.

Bottle. Lemon, biscuit malt, and astringent hay aroma. Lightly hazy golden yellow with small head. Moderately sweet lemon/orange, biscuit malt, and mildly bitter astringent hay flavor. Good body. Solid.

(750ml bottle) - Huge amount of pressure when popping the cork. Didnt blow. But, if could have if I wasnt care enough. Half the glass is filled with foam. Golden body with lots of big bubbles coming from the bottom of the glass. Aroma of clove with slight banana. First flavor is of banana. But, theres a lot of bitterness that comes out pretty quickly. Im definitely picking up the sweetness the description mentions. Definitely preferred the Valar Morghulis over this one, though the Seven Kingdoms was my favorite so far.

Expressive and complete and sound, hitting the mark for old world Tripel, endlessly drinkable  From bottle its lightly hazed amber-gold with a lasting sticky head. Enjoyably phenolic and ester-driven nose is mineral-like and peppery with soft banana esters, light touches of basement / must, Hops are understated (properly) and manifest as herbs, flowers, apricot, lemon. In the mouth its medium-full bodied and balanced, tending off-dry but seemingly more acidic than dry. That crisp acidity and supple-fine natural carbonation suiting the dominant candy sugar and backgrounded honey and toast maltiness.

Dark golden. Creamy white foam is mostly lasting. Clean honeysuckle, poundcake, apricot, cake frosting, and puttylike yeast aromatics. Fluffy and expansive carbonation with some crunchy edges. Rich, palate-enveloping wave of candy sugar laps the tongue before a cleansing punch of flowery hops and a staunch black-pepper phenolic surge. Strikingly firm and cleanly extracted pils malt is exceptionally buoyant, providing a stiffness that reinforces the immaculate attenuation and mirroring the woody hop underpinnings. An apricot fruitiness sparkles vibrantly as it links up with a wheatlike slickness, but a cottony dryness keeps the slickness perfectly at bay. Lemony acids gracefully wash over the palate, adding levity to the sugar-charged body which continually causes the lips to smack. Touches of marmalade, dried apricot and a rummy richness align with the dry piecrusty malt. Alcohol is expertly cloaked within. Yeast leaves its clean but rustic mark all over the body with a dusty and puttylike characteristic, as a nearly-airy phenolic note vivifies the elegant hopping. Dense, nectar-infused herbal bitterness digs deeper into the palate before merging with the dusty yeast and browned banana-bread notes. Well-attenuated finish is cohesively composed of flowers, honeycomb and a lengthy, fresh squeezed sugarcane juice aftertaste. As with the stellar dubbel in this series, this is absolutely spot-on to style and immediately evokes the Old World upon nosing the glass. What it might lack in complexity and dynamism, makes up for it with its focus, not to mention a fermentation character that couldnt be more polished. Awesome German hop character, to boot! A terrific example of the style.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Gift from K while visiting DC, drank on Election Night 2016 while nail biting through returns. Appears orange in low light, with a brighter light orange-tinted yellow. Nice white head initially, falling to a modest head. Honeyed nose, hint of orange. In the mouth, immediately struck by high gravity sweetness. Continued honey citrus, mild biitterness. Finishes on a bit of a bitter note. Rather intense, fine carbonation. Typically for myself, Im not a fan of higher alcohol, high residual sweetness beers, so I could take or leave this one.
Medium yellow and hazy. Nice floral and sweet aroma. Taste was a good ale with yeast and thick sugars. Not too heavy. Tap
A bit of grain, some honey maybe at the beginning, finishes dry with some notable hop bitterness for this style - but not too much bitterness. Some spicy yeast notes throughout. Not bad.

Bottle:
Slightly hazy amber with a small, off-white head.
Orange marmalade, oatmeal aroma.
Taste is sweet, and almost syrupy orange malt, oatmeal, honey...maybe a hint of banana...
A little spice and warmth....sweet, heavy, candied....I think I caught some cantaloupe accents in there, too......Quite excellent.
Pours a cloudy gold from bottle. Big white head. Yeast sugar bananas and spice. Good

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2016 750 ml poured into a chalice. Orange gold color with a pillowy white head that lasts quite a while. Banana, a distinctly Belgian yeast, sweet bread, marshmallows, and a hint of hops. Initial taste is more sweet bread, coriander, fruity, caramelized brown sugar. Aftertaste is a hint of grassy hops, bread, and yeast. Full and smooth mouthfeel with just a bit of carbonation. Nicely done! I?ve had some awkwardly hoppy tripels but this is like a mini Quad.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours gold with a white head. Taste sweet, Belgian yeast, some spice. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear amber with a very thick buff head. Aroma offers malty, oaten, woody, yeasty, and subtle honey and fruity notes. Flavor nicely echoes the aroma but ramps up the fruit and adds a little wheat and citrus. Mouthfeel features decent body and woody fizz. Answer the call.

750mL bottle. Slightly hazy, old gold color, decent white head, effervescent. Nose is fruity funk, band aids, white pepper, grass. Mouth is medium bodied, sweet, sharp carbonation, crackers, yeasty spice, candy sugar, Meyer lemon, wet paper. Too sweet. Not my favorite of the series. Fuck the Cubs.
Draft: Apricot and lemon nose. Hazy amber, medium head, good lace. Apricot, apple, slightly, tinny. Medium body, easy carbonation, warm.

On tap at Hops & Pie. Yellow and lightly hazy in appearance with a fluffy, lasting white head. Pleasant aroma of toasted grain, mild noble hops, light Belgian yeast, citrus zest and a light peppery spice. Similar flavor, adding mild bitterness and mild sweetness with hints of candy sugar and a trace of alcohol. Medium body with a crisp and pretty clean feel overall. Well done.

500ml bottle, split with a friend. Poured a clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma was light banana, clove. Light spice notes, sweetness - malts. Banana? Wheat. Fine, but not their strongest offering of this series.

Pours golden with a pillow of white topping. Aroma is yeasty spice, grassy notes and mild sweet of honey. Tastes of coriander, lemon zest, cracked pepper, and candi sugar with just a hint of booze. Finishes both tart and sweet. Very nice example of the style.

On tap in SC. 
Clear golden-amber body with a large whit head supported by lively, medium-high carbonation. 
Lightly fruity. Moderately complex for style. Some oak on display in the appealing aftertaste.

Bomber from Whole Foods Market Fair Lakes (Virginia)
Aroma: bubblegum, earthy, honey, cloves, biscuit
Appearance: clear golden with a huge white head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, lively, long finish, 

Delicious
Bubblegum, orange, and sweet dough aromas. Taste is bubblegum esters, orange slices, slight banana peel, and sweet dough malts.

The pour is hazy and orange with a thin creamy white head. The aroma on the beer is excellent. Belgian candy sugar, honey, apricot. Flavor and palate are nice. Quality tripel all around. Reminds me a bit of la fin de monde.
Really good. Pretty intense in the finish but it is tasty and really easy to drink.

Cloudy gold, sparse lace. 
Full body, flavorful, very rich and hot mouthfeel, lingering aftertaste. 
Moderately bittersweet bit dryish finish. 
Hoppy, resiny, fruity, touch of yeast. 
Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Poured hazy golden color with an average frothy white head that lasted with good lacing. Complex yeast and sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium yeast sweet finish of moderate duration. This is a refreshing beer.

It pours hazy orange with a large white head. The aroma has bananas, herbal hops, rich malt and caramel. It has a medium full body with a lot of carbonation. The taste has herbal spicy hops, dried bananas, alcohol, Abbey yeast and drier malt. Good.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2016 Draft at Bru Craft. Very hazy gold pour an off-white foamy ring. Minimal lace. Feels like sweet lemony Belgium Tripel. Coriander. Medium caramel malts. Reconstituted dried lemon and orange peels. Green peppercorns. Chipotle. Eucalyptus. Honeycomb. Fragrant and flavorful but hints at an herbal lemon cough drop. Not the best in the GoT series but not the worst.
From a 75 cl. bottle. Pours a clear gold with ample carbonation and a big off white head. Aroma of banana and bread dough. Flavors of coriander and honey. Smooth, sweet finish.
Pours a hazy golden color with a large beady white head. Sweet mouthfeel with heavy biting carbonation. Notes of baked bread, honey, clover, Belgian yeast, and cardboard.

Hazy deep golden with a thin foamy white head. Nice estery and lightly funky nose and a trippel malty tone. Crisp and full Belgian blonde malt flavor thats strong and lightly estery, trippel tones like from an abbey, and a clean lightly dusty finish. Really wonderful.

750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have sweet malts, honey, floral notes, yeast, fruity, decent triple, though not my favorite style.

750ml c&c bottle with enough pressure to shoot the cork out like a bullet once the cage was removed. Poured a dark gold thick body under a giant rocky off white head. Aroma/flavor of sugar, Belgian yeast, banana peels, white pepper, spice, wet wheat, earthy grains, bubblegum and more sugar. Big full chewy body with a lingering sugary aftertaste. Too sweet overall.

Bottle from Brewtopia. Hazy golden orange with lasting head and lace. Spicy peppery banana vanilla honey fresh bread aroma. Vanilla apricot bready sweetness with peppery spicy grassy bitterness in medium dry finish. Medium full very soft body. I love tripels and this one has all the makings of a classic. FUCKIN NAILED IT!
hay, roasty, earthy, golden, hazy, rocky head, medium bitterness, light body, average carbonation, bitter,

4oz draft at B Side two days ago. Hazy gold with small white head. Shared with GenDV110+OT, we managed to finish an ounce or so between us. Left the rest for the drain. My notes, verbatim: "Banana yeast belgian spice wheat yuck". Add in "boozy mess" and there you go.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2016 Bottle (the XL080416BBT2 batch!).

Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy dark yellow.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, cracker), moderately hoppy (honeysuckle flowers, herbs), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, basement), with notes of pepper, gum, alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Ommegang was pretty mediocre for quite a lot of years there, and they still are somewhat hit-and-miss to this day, but they are capable of some seriously yummy, authentic, no-bullshit stuff the past 5 years or so. This is one of those beers where they dont mess things up with spices or too much or too little of anything. This is right on the money for a real Tripel, even if I might want it just a BIT more complex and dry in the finish. Just a bit...so close to mind-melting though, right on that high 3s / low 4s borderline. Its yeasty, its bright, its phenolic, its got just the right amount of alcohol warmth, its clean...you really couldnt ask for much better, especially from an American brewery (even if theyre owned by a Belgian one, obviously). No junky banana or syrupy sweetness or stupid spices...they keep it real, son...and it works. AND they only charge $10 for a 750mL bottle...which may not be great, but it sure as hell is better than a lot of scam artists charging 50-100% more for grossly flawed product. I hate that its in 750mL bottles, though, honestly, because its so good that its hard not to punish my liver with the whole thing in one night (despite one of my good friends being able to enjoy a re-capped/corked bottle 24 hours later, I never have been able to find the same joy the next night, so I either dump the remainder or just go ahead and punish my body with most/all of it). Right up there with Allagash for one of the most authentic Tripels you can find in North America (Boulevard used to be great too, but alas...they are long since off their game). UPDATE: beware batch XL080316BBT1, which is what Ommegang put in the holiday gift packs...its a butter-and-wort drain pour!

750 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 8/17/2016. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy golden amber color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big lemon, orange, pear, apple, peach, apricot, white grape, peppercorn, clove, coriander, light banana/bubblegum, honey, biscuit, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, moderate bready/candi sugar malt, and earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of huge lemon, orange, pear, apple, peach, apricot, white grape, peppercorn, clove, coriander, light banana/bubblegum, honey, biscuit, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of yeast spiciness and moderate herbal/grassy hop bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, orange, pear, apple, peach, apricot, white grape, peppercorn, clove, coriander, light banana/bubblegum, honey, biscuit, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, moderate bready/candi sugar malt, and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitter/spiciness balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitter/spiciness and carbonation; increasing through the glass. Medium-high carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, moderate crisp, creamy/bready/grainy, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is awesome. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is an incredible tripel! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, moderate bready/candi sugar malt, and earthy hop flavors; very smooth, crisp, and dangerously easy to sip on for the ABV. A really amazing offering all around.

4 oz pour on draft at B Side. Shared by DCLawyer, thanks Jason! Clear golden orange with off-white head. Aromas of herbs, spice, malt. Tastes of herbs, malt, citrus, light spice. Medium body with a dry finish.
Golden with a white topper. Overripened banana, juicy tropical fruit, honey, spicy clive-centric finish. Medium to full body. Another standout from the gang.

Gold. Great nose of Belgian yeast, citrus and light overripe fruit. Flavor is citrus with Belgian yeast, faint overripe banana, and mild hop bitterness. Dry, but not overly. Some sweet syrupy goodness. Good carb. Excellent.

Bottle from Whole Foods In Redwood City, CA. Aroma is vanilla, floral, bubblegum, vanilla bubblegum, apple banana, maybe even some caramel popcorn. Taste is natural vanilla, apple banana, spicy cloves. Creamy, spicy, natural vanilla and floral notes. Maybe its been too long since Ive had a Belgian... this was especially good.

Pours hazy gold with a white head. Aroma seems banana clove. Med + body. Flavor is very clove with hints of banana and maybe pineapple. Earthy. Clove finish. Strong in flavor - very tasty. Clove to the edge, but not over.

750mL, corked and caged. Nose of honey and estery Belgian yeast, touch of dust and bright sunshine, grainy Pils; has that nice hint of mustiness and wood but otherwise fruit and citrus line the edges. Otherwise wheat and heavy, Hefeweizen-like banana. Pour very pale but ends up rich golden in the glass, head is large, rocky, and lacing white. Taste semi-dry, its grainy (graininess lasts into the aftertaste) and mildly bitter (clean) but yeast combined with the hops are giving jammy banana and orange notes, less lemon peel. Smooth full body but not fat, rather dense and finely articulated, again rallying the spirits of grain and minerally esters. Drying lightly chalky feel, average carbonation and a bit of yeast despite by careful pour. Fresh and vibrant, alcohol hidden well, dusty Saaz/Poperinge base, honey, some interesting amber-copper and wooden notes, tannic dryness as if it picked up something from a barrel (supposition only). Digestible!  Simple and worthy. [2016.10.11: 4.0]
750 ml bottle cork and caged. Nice looking pour. Sweet banana aroma followed by notes of banana and candy. Very good and well balanced and subtle.
